1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested technical assistance (TA) to support reform 
of its civil service administration. Assistance in this area is considered to be most effective if 
activities are closely linked to the formulation and implementation of the new civil service law. 
The country operations business plan 2008–20101 includes an advisory TA for supporting civil 
service reform in the 2008 TA program.2 The November 2007 Fact-Finding Mission reached an 
understanding with the Government on the TA's impact and outcome, scope, cost and financing, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. Subsequently, some 
adjustments were made based on progress with formulating the new law. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam’s current civil service administration, developed under the centrally planned 
economy system, needs substantial reform to meet requirements resulting from recent rapid 
socioeconomic development. It needs to more effectively satisfy the needs of customers and 
focus on results and outcomes. This requires a review of the entire civil service administration, 
followed by activities to improve organizational and individual performance. 
 
3.  By  the  end  of  2006,  of  the  approximately  1.8  million  civil  servants,3 240,000  were 
employed by government agencies4 and 1.4 million by public service providers such as schools 
and health centers. The remaining 160,000 were employed by the National Assembly, the Office 
of the Government, people’s courts, people’s prosecutors, and party agencies. 
 
4.  The career employment system is one of the weaknesses of the current civil service. 
Guaranteed  lifetime  employment  and  seniority-based  promotion  systems  have  made  the 
Government’s  human  resource  management  rigid  and  inflexible,  and  tend  to  lower  civil 
servants’  motivation  to  improve  their  outputs.  Generic  and  unclear  job  descriptions  have 
resulted in recruitment difficulties, i.e., recruiting the most suitable person for the position. 
Among various selection criteria, importance is attached to academic background rather than 
the candidate’s overall competence to pursue the specific task. Weak job descriptions create 
difficulties for performance evaluation because the rater and the ratee often do not share a clear 
and common understanding of the required competence and tasks to be accomplished. Many 
government agencies do not have an well-articulated human resource management plan based 
on an overall organization-specific business plan. This inhibits effective staff recruitment and 
promotion, and development and provision of appropriate training programs. Existing training 
courses are designed to meet general requirements. They tend to be similar to school classes 
and in many cases do not offer specific knowledge required for specific assignments. 
 
5.  One of the main objectives of the 2001–2010 Public Administration Reform Master 
Program  is  to  build  a modern  and  professional  public  administration  by  improving quality, 
competence, and ethics of civil servants; and improving operating efficiency and effectiveness 
of  government  agencies  and  public  service  providers.  Several  initiatives  have  been

2   
implemented to achieve this objective. The revision of the Ordinance of Public Officials and Civil 
Servants  in  2003  promoted  decentralization  of  human  resource  management  of  technical 
officials to line ministries and local governments. Salary reform increased minimum and average 
salaries for civil servants. Basic training courses are now mandatory for all civil servants.  
 
6.  To promote civil service reform, the Government decided to establish a civil service law. 
The Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) prepared a draft law and submitted it to the National 
Assembly in May 2008. The proposed law will address existing issues and problems, and 
initiate substantial transformation of the all civil service institutions to meet emerging needs. 
 
7.  The draft law proposes introducing position-based management. This helps develop 
clear  and  specific  job  description  and  classify  civil  servants  by  qualifications,  tasks,  and 
responsibilities. This is one of the conditions that enables fair and open performance evaluation, 
and a results-based civil service management system. The draft law proposes to distinguish civil 
servants employed by government agencies from those employed by public service providers. 
This will contribute to the process of delegating authority to public service providers and improve 
the quality of public service delivery. It is also expected to be an important step toward reform 
for civil servants’ salaries. 
 
8.  However, improvements are still needed in the draft civil service law. A shift from the 
systems of lifetime employment and seniority-based ranking to the merit-based system must be 
clearly articulated in the law to ensure accountability in performance evaluation and promotion 
of civil servants. As the basis for recruitment, training, and performance evaluation, minimum 
standards  of  qualifications  for  all  civil  service  positions  should  be  identified.  The  training 
program needs to be reformed to accommodate specific needs of different civil service positions. 
A mechanism to monitor the training programs should be introduced to maintain the quality of 
training. The National Assembly, considering the deficiencies in the draft law, asked MOHA to 
strengthen the draft and resubmit it for approval at the Assembly’s fall 2008 session.  
 
9.  Civil service reform is a long-term process. Establishment of an action plan with clear 
priorities, timeline, responsibilities, and resources is recommended to support implementation of 
the  proposed  civil  service  law.  Furthermore,  the  related  decrees  and  circulars  to  guide 
implementation of the law should be issued promptly following approval of the law. The TA will 
help strengthen the contents of the draft law, and implement the law efficiently and thoroughly. 
 
10.  ADB has been involved in the early stages of development of the draft law. Under TA to 
support  implementation  of  training  reform, 5  ADB  facilitated  an  international  consultative 
workshop in June 2006 for government officials to learn experiences and practices in civil 
service reform in People’s Republic of China, New Zealand, Thailand, and United Kingdom. 
Subsequently, ADB supported MOHA in organizing two consultation workshops in December 
2007 to discuss the draft law with various stakeholders. The United Nations Development 
Programme and Swedish International Development Assistance have expressed willingness to 
coordinate with ADB in helping prepare and implement the civil service law.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The expected impact of the TA is enhanced quality of public service delivery as a result 
of simplifying administrative procedures of public agencies and improving efficiency of public 
investment. The TA is expected to develop an integrated civil service reform policy framework to 
facilitate the introduction of results-based management in the civil service The policy framework 
will help (i) introduce a merit-based system with clear and specific job descriptions and minimum 
qualification standards for all civil service positions; (ii) ensure fair and accountable recruitment, 
performance evaluation, and promotion; and (iii) improve training programs to meet specific 
needs of civil servants.  
 
12.  The TA has three expected outputs: (i) strengthened draft civil service law, (ii) facilitation 
of implementation of the law, and (iii) capacity building. The first output will provide underlying 
principles and key directions for reforming current civil service management, and introduce 
these principles in the revised draft law. The second output will contribute to the creation of an 
enabling environment for implementation of the new law; and the third output will help build 
capacity to guide and monitor implementation of the law. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
13.  The activities to be covered by the TA include (i) consolidated diagnostic studies on 
existing civil service management including review of related laws and regulations; (ii) analysis 
of experiences and lessons of other countries in reforming management of their civil service;  
(iii) identification of areas that need improvement in existing civil service management and 
preparation of recommendations for improvements; (iv) formulation of a public service reform 
policy framework; (v) review of the current draft civil service law and identification of deficiencies; 
and (vi) finalization of the draft law for submission to the National Assembly for approval at its 
fall  2008  session.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  in  implementing  the  law  through 
development of decrees and/or circulars to guide implementation of the law. An action plan 
identifying specific actions to be taken with clear priorities, time frame, responsibilities, and 
resources will be developed and executed under the TA. 
 
14.  The TA will help the Government promote the understanding and commitment of civil 
servants to civil service reform. The TA will support the organization of dissemination workshops 
to  provide  key  central  and  provincial  stakeholders  with  information  on  (i)  the  importance, 
rationale, mandate, and key issues of the new law; and (ii) policies to reform civil service 
management institution under the law. The TA will help with capacity development activities 
such as training courses for personnel managers, particularly for MOHA officials, focusing  
(i)  human  resource  management,  (ii)  change  management,  and  (iii)  leadership  and 
management.  Close  collaboration  with  the  national  training  institutions  in  designing  and 
delivering training courses is needed to ensure sustainability of the training programs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $1,000,000 on a 
grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance $250,000 equivalent, 
mainly in kind, by providing counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative support 
services, logistics, and necessary data. The details of the cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2.

4   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MOHA will be the Executing Agency for the TA and MOHA’s Civil Service Department 
will be the focal point for TA implementation. MOHA, through the Civil Service Department, will 
provide overall guidance for TA implementation, ensure interagency coordination, and issue 
appropriate directives and decisions. MOHA will appoint a senior official as project director. The 
project working group will comprise representatives from related MOHA departments and other 
government agencies. To facilitate smooth TA implementation, the working group will meet 
quarterly and as required to monitor TA implementation progress and ensure the TA objectives 
are achieved. ADB will participate in the working group meetings.  
 
17.  The TA will have two phases: (i) finalization of the draft civil service law for submission to 
the 2008 fall session of the National Assembly (phase 1), and (ii) facilitation of implementation 
of the new law and capacity building (phase 2). Phase 1 will require 3.5 person-months of 
international and 7 person-months of national consulting services. The international consultants 
will provide expertise in overall civil service management (2 person-months) and performance 
management  and  competency-based  management  (1.5  person-months).  The  national 
consultants  will  provide  expertise  in  legal  aspects  (3.5  person-months)  and  civil  service 
management (3.5 person-months). They will be selected and contracted individually as they are 
needed urgently to help the Government finalize the draft law and submit it to the National 
Assembly for its 2008 fall session. Phase 2 will require 13 person-months of international and 
30 person-months of national consulting. The international consultants will have expertise in 
overall  civil  service  management  (8 person-months),  performance  management  and 
competency-based management (3 person-months), and code of conduct (2 person-months). 
The national consultants will provide expertise in legal aspects (8.5 person-months), civil service 
management  (11.5  person-months),  capacity  building  (5  person-months),  and  advocacy  
(5 person-months). They will be recruited through a firm using the quality- and cost-based 
selection method and simplified technical proposal procedures. The TA will engage international 
and domestic resource persons who have expertise in civil service reform and capacity building. 
ADB will engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. Procurement of equipment for the TA will be undertaken in accordance with ADB's 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  equipment  will  be 
transferred to MOHA upon TA completion. A study tour will be organized for senior officials 
directly involved in implementing the law. The objective of the study tour will be to share the 
best practices and hands-on experiences in civil service reform in other countries, particularly 
those with similar reform processes.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years, from September 2008 to September 2011. 
Each individual consultant and the consulting firm are required to produce the following major 
reports:  (i)  an  inception  report  describing  the  detailed  work  program  3  weeks  after 
commencement of the assignment, (ii) progress reports during the assignment, and (iii) a final 
report describing the detailed findings and recommendations with regard to the specific tasks 
assigned  before  completion  of  the  assignment.  The  consultants  will  submit  reports  and 
documents to MOHA (in English and Vietnamese) and ADB (in English). ADB will conduct 
inception and review missions, and participate in tripartite meetings involving the Government, 
ADB, and consultants to review TA progress.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Supporting Civil Service Reform, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
A.   Phase 1: Individual Consultants 
 
1.  International  Civil  Service  Management  Specialist  and  Team  Leader (2 person-
months). The consultant will have a strong background and experience in human resource 
management in developed and developing countries, particularly in merit-based management 
systems,  classification  of  civil  servants,  recruitment,  promotion,  performance  assessment, 
reward systems, and training. The consultant will report to the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) 
and the Asian Development Bank (ADB); provide regular work reports as may be required by 
MOHA in addition to those set forth in the technical assistance (TA) report (para. 18); and follow 
regulations and policies of the Government, particularly those of MOHA. Tasks will include the 
following: 
 
(i)   Provide expertise and support in implementing the following activities: 
 
(a)  Review  and  consolidate  diagnostic  studies  of  the  current  civil  service 
management  system,  including  those  of  earlier  assistance  projects 
provided by ADB and other development partners. 
(b)  Help formulate an integrated policy framework for reforming the entire civil 
service system, including adoption of merit-based principles and reform of 
classification  of  civil  servants,  recruitment,  promotion,  performance 
assessment, reward system, training, and code of conduct. 
(c)  Review the current draft law, provide inputs for strengthening the draft, and 
help conduct an impact assessment. 
(d)   Identify  and  recommend  policy  issues  that  need  implementing  decrees 
and/or circulars. 
 
(ii)  Review the detailed implementation plan for phase 1 of the TA:  
 
(iii)  Act as the team leader for phase 1 of the TA, coordinate the work of other 
international and national consultants, and collaborate with other development 
partners to enhance the impact of ADB assistance. 
 
(iv)   Ensure quality of TA outputs under phase 1. 
 
(v)   Prepare inception, progress, and final TA reports for phase 1. 
 
2.  International  Performance  Management  and  Competency-Based  Management 
Specialist (1.5 person-months). The consultant will have a strong background and experience 
in  results-based  and  performance  management  policies  and  practices  in  developed  and 
developing countries. The consultant will work closely with the team leader and report to MOHA 
and ADB; provide regular work reports as may be required by MOHA in addition to those set 
forth  in  the  TA  report  (para.  18);  and  follow  regulations  and  policies  of  the  Government, 
particularly those of MOHA. Tasks will include the following: 
   
(i)  Help  introduce  and  institutionalize  the  concept  of  a  national  competency 
framework for civil servants for ensuring minimum qualification standards.

10  Appendix 3 
(ii)  Formulate  a  policy  framework  for  the  integrated  reform  of  the  civil  service 
administration based on competencies and work outputs.  
 
(iii)  Support MOHA in developing policies and practices for managing civil servants 
that  emphasize  competencies  and  work  outputs,  including  performance 
assessment, and specifically provide recommendations for shifting to position-
based management. 
 
(iv)  Prepare inception, progress, and final TA reports in the assigned areas. 
 
3.   National  Legal  Expert  (3.5  person-months).  The  consultant  will  have  a  strong 
background in legal aspects, good understanding and extensive experience in drafting laws in 
Viet Nam, and extensive experience in public administration. The consultant will work closely 
with the team leader and report to MOHA and ADB; provide regular work reports as may be 
required by MOHA; and follow regulations and policies of the Government, particularly those of 
MOHA. Tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Provide inputs in finalizing the draft law, such as review of related regulations 
and comments from stakeholders on the draft law, and provide recommendations 
for strengthening the draft law taking into account issues of legal consistency.  
 
(ii)  Assist  in  conducting  consultative  workshops  with  stakeholders  following  the 
Government’s required legal drafting process.  
 
(iii)  Provide necessary inputs in finalizing the draft law for submission to the National 
Assembly. 
 
(iv)  Prepare inception, progress, and final TA reports in the assigned areas. 
 
4.  National Civil Service Management Specialist (3.5 person-months). The consultant 
will have a strong background in human resource management and Viet Nam’s civil service 
administration.  The  consultant  will  have  a  good  understanding  on  results-based  and 
performance management policies and practices. The consultant will work closely with the team 
leader and report to MOHA and ADB; provide regular work reports as may be required by 
MOHA; and follow regulations and policies of the Government, particularly those of MOHA. 
Tasks include the following: 
 
(i)   Provide expertise for implementation of the following activities: 
 
(a)  Help  review  diagnostic  studies  of  current  civil  servant  management, 
including analysis of issues and challenges of the current system. 
(b)  Help analyze the experience and lessons of other countries in reforming 
civil service systems. 
(c)  Help  formulate  a  policy  framework  for  the  renovated  civil  service 
administration. 
(d)  Provide  inputs  for  the  review  of  the  draft  civil  service  law  and  its 
finalization. 
 
(ii)  Assist the team leader in reviewing and revising the detailed implementation plan 
for phase 1 of the TA.

(iii)  Assist the team leader in preparing inception, progress, and final TA reports for 
phase 1. 
 
(iv)  Assist  the  team  leader  and  other  consultants  in  working  with  government 
agencies. 
 
B.  Phase 2: Consulting Firm 
 
5.  The consultant team will comprise an international civil service management specialist 
(8 person-months),  international  performance  management  and  competency-based 
management specialist (3 person-months), international code of conduct specialist (2 person-
months),  national  legal  specialist  (8.5  person-months),  national  civil  service  management 
specialist (11.5 person-months), national capacity-building specialist (5 person-months), and 
national advocacy specialist (5 person-months). The consultant team will report to MOHA and 
ADB; provide regular work reports as may be required by MOHA, in addition to those set forth in 
the TA report (para. 18); and follow regulations and policies of the Government, particularly 
those of MOHA. The international civil service management specialist will act as the team 
leader of phase 2 of the TA, coordinate the work of other international and national consultants, 
consolidate their inputs into the TA reports, and collaborate with other development partners to 
enhance the impact of ADB assistance. The consultant team will produce inception, progress, 
and final TA reports for phase 2. 
 
6.  Development of Decrees and Circulars. The consultant team will provide inputs for the 
development of decrees and circulars to guide implementation of the new civil service law. They 
will include code of conduct for civil servants, job description, recruitment process, performance 
assessment, staff promotion, reward system, training program, human resource management 
information  system,  and  monitoring  and  supervision.  The  consultant  team  will  help  the 
Government issue necessary decrees and circulars promptly following approval of the law.  
 
7.  Establishment of Action Plan. The consultant team will assist in establishing an action 
plan  that  identifies  specific  actions  with  clear  priorities,  time  frame,  responsibilities,  and 
resources. Focus will be given to the following aspects: 
 
(i)  implementation of a merit-based system supported by clear and specific job 
descriptions and minimum qualification standards for all civil service positions;  
 
(ii)  fair and accountable procedures for recruitment, performance evaluation, and 
promotion; and  
 
(iii)  thorough implementation of a code of conduct to strengthen ethical standards of 
civil servants. 
 
8.  Advocacy Activities. The consultant team will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Develop strategies and a plan for awareness-raising and advocacy activities.  
 
(ii)  Develop a detailed plan for communication and advocacy activities.  
 
(iii)  Support MOHA in implementing awareness-raising and advocacy activities.  
 
(iv)  Design public and media campaign programs and materials.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  Identify  various  mediums  and  channels,  e.g.,  visual  aids,  printed  materials, 
organized forums, to ensure stakeholders understand and support the new law. 
 
9.  Capacity Building. The consultant team will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Identify  capacity  development  needs for TA  implementation  and  civil  service 
management reform. 
 
(ii)  Develop a capacity development plan. 
 
(iii)  Support the implementation of capacity development activities such as training 
workshops, training programs, and study tours. 
 
(iv)  Monitor and assess results and impact of the capacity development activities.
